posts.cooked:
Last year we weren’t able to get it to work (probably user error on our part) This year we got it to work, but just haven’t had time to dig into the details/ do any analysis on the output. I haven’t updated the slides to include that.

There was some issue with the drive system we were running and the logs. We changed drive systems and that seems to have fixed it. We were going to test it monday but ran into an issue with how to start the test. for some reason the assigned button wasn’t calling the test (probably again user error on our end) so we just manually tuned the drive system.

No intentional shade at the SYSID tool – the “It doesn’t work great” should probably be changed to “We are still working on figuring out how it actually works”

Luke’s Incredibly informal overview of control theory And how to control a FIRST robot

Updated and in pptx form

On slide 27, there should be some sort of note that there is a maximum you can set the derivative gain to before your system goes unstable due to latency. This latency limitation on derivative is extremely relevant in FRC because the controllers don’t run that fast. When you have too much latency, you will start seeing sustained oscillations, follows by instability if you increase the derivative gain.

Adding integral control will not reduce oscillations in most cases (and usually makes them marginally rose), its only job is to eliminate steady-state error. And actually, I prefer to tune the I gain first so you are sure the integral control isn’t doing something stupid. And then is also when I’d make sure your integral limits are doing what you expect them to do and that your anti-windup works. You can normalize the integral caps to motor output by dividing the limits by the integral gain which is very convince for tuning.

On slide 25, integral windup is usually causes when you saturate the input, resulting in the system not being able to give you any more input, causing non-sense to happen when you keep on asking the system for more input. The 1-line fix to that is to only integrate if you are not saturated or if the integral is reducing the overall buildup.

On slide 29, you skipped like 20 steps between feedforward control and MPC. MPC is incredibly hard to implement and making it not viable for most FRC teams, and is also extremely computationally expensive, making it even more not viable. After adding feedforwards, the next step if you wanted more performance would be to use a model to tune the feedback controlers and identify the paramters (doesn’t need to be using WPIlibs sysid, there are many ways of identifying paramters) or using LQR (which also needs a model), and then using more optimal more optimal motion profiles (which are hard to derive, but much easier than MPC still). If you’ve exhausted all of those, then and only then would I think about considering MPC in FRC .

Good points

slide 27: I’ve generally heard those oscillations called “Chatter” --mentioned in slide 26. Are you referring to that or something else?

Integral will not reduce oscillations…: got anything to read on that? I was framing it simply wrt to how i was taught to tune PIDs… increase P to the point it oscilates, increase I until it stops. etc. that said i agree. it meshes with what the math says.  I’ll update the definition.

slide 25: is it worth getting into that level of detail? I was just trying to give them a gut feeling of how things work. I can add it if you’d like

slide 29: yeah i was going to go into LQR and MPC but i actually knocked them out (or thought i did) I’ll go thru and kill MPC and stop at feed forward

Cheers

Bobnet:

Integral will not reduce oscillations…: got anything to read on that? I was framing it simply wrt to how i was taught to tune PIDs… increase P to the point it oscilates, increase I until it stops. etc. that said i agree. it meshes with what the math says. I’ll update the definition.

The most direct answer would be to take a look at classical control theory. Integral control adds another pole (free integrator) to the system, which does not delete the effects of the rest of the system dynamics. This changes the closed-loop dynamics to change to have more poles than zeros so that the steady state error is eliminated, but also adds a zero to the closed loop transfer function which causes more oscillations and overshoot. Its this zero which is annoying and you can’t do much about, and also is frequently the reason why poorly-tuned integral controllers misbehave if they don’t saturate.

Or the informal way; “how does adding more output decrease oscillations”? (It doesn’t). Its only job is to eliminate steady-state error.

Bobnet:

slide 27: I’ve generally heard those oscillations called “Chatter” --mentioned in slide 26. Are you referring to that or something else?

No. Unless google is lying to me, chatter refers to derivative control’s tendency to amplify noise which is a completely separate problem with derivative control. (Its not a standardized term either). Latency destabilizing the controller is its own problem that can be re-created in simulations easily with a perfect everything else.
makes sense, generally use a low pass on the front off my d controller

Low passing the derivative fixes noise, but makes the latency problem worse by adding more phase lag (lowering both the gain and phase margins, think of the phase plot). On an industrial robot running at 10 khz, yea latency isn’t a problem and derivative noise or the zero are more likely to ruin you. But for an FRC system communicating over a can bus with too many birds and squids screaming on them, latency is an incredibly large problem

i haven’t dug too deep into the docs for ctre or rev, but i assume they do some prefiltering on the derivative signal on the 10khz controllers (Talon, sparkmax etc.) …

I don’t think our team has run into latency destabalization yet (knock on wood) but i know its an exponential  (e^-ks).

Bobnet:

I don’t think our team has run into latency destabalization yet (knock on wood) but i know its an exponential (e^-ks).

Chances are its because you aren’t trying to maximize performance out of controller yet. When you only set P and D once, you aren’t gonna be very aggressive, but you can keep on increasing the gains to increase system bandwidth until you get latency limited (increase P again, increase D to remove the overshoot, increase P more, increase D more to remove the overshoot), and this process can get you like 80ish% of the performance of sysiding the system and tuning feedback from the model (inertia feedforwards always requires an accurate model tho). In my experience in FRC and college robotics, latency is the #1 limiting factor and comes into play well before other limitations except for sometimes saturation.
